awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Transformation Elastodynamics and its Application to Wave Control in Solids
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project supports fundamental research needed to realize mechanisms of control of waves in solids. Information and energy in the world travel from one point to another in the form of waves. Examples include electromagnetic waves such as light and radio waves, sound waves in air and water, and elastic waves in solids. The ability to control the flow of these waves, therefore, indirectly leads to the ability to control the information and energy which these waves represent. Strong material design mechanisms have recently been developed to control the flow of electromagnetic and acoustic waves. However, controlling waves in solids has proven to be more difficult, and resolving associated challenges is the main focus of this project. This research will have beneficial impact on several U.S. economic, security, and energy interests. It will lead to improvements in the design of vibration sensors, transducers, and imaging devices with applications to various industries such as aerospace, automobile, civil infrastructure. It will lead to novel earthquake mitigation techniques for civil structures and vibration mitigation techniques for sensitive industry equipment. Through the various outreach efforts proposed here, this research will help in broadening the participation of the general public in the highly multi-disciplinary subject of waves and their control.

Transformation methods have emerged as effective tools for the control of electromagnetic and acoustic waves. However, analogous successes have not been achieved for elastodynamics (waves in solids). This research aims to fill the knowledge gap by investigating a coupled constitutive form (Willis form) as the basis upon which the principles and applications of transformation elastodynamics can be built. Furthermore, this research aims to provide fundamental limits and bounds on the performance of any transformation device through the application of causality principle and scattering theory. The PI will conduct theoretical studies into elastodynamic homogenization, performance bounds of transformation-elastodynamic devices and will assess performance gains through the application of classes of Euclidean and non-Euclidean transformations. Level-set based parallel computational algorithms will be also developed for inverse design of transformation-based devices. Three-dimensional printed models of transformation-elastodynamic devices, at both the unit cell and the device levels, will be fabricated and tested through ultrasonic wave measurements for experimental verification.

por.por_cntn:
This project was aimed at understanding how to create metamaterials for the fine tuned control of elastic waves in solid media. During the course of this project, several intellectual contributions were made in the broad areas of wave control and metamaterial design.

Intellectual merits: It was shown, for example, that exotic wave phenomenon such as negative refraction and negative material properties (such as negative density) are possible in extremely simple composite materials such as a simple laminated composite. On the other end of the spectrum, highly complex 3D composite structures were revealed using topology optimization which exhibited record (at the time) wide frequency ranges in which no sound propagation is possible (bandgap). Advancements were also made in the area of numerical algorithms suitable for the study of these systems. These included new algorithms optimized for running on Graphical Processing Units, XFEM based algorithms which do not require the underlying mesh to correspond to the features (such as boundaries and interfaces) of the composite under study, algorithms which leverage Deep Neural Networks (one of the first application of these networks in the area of mechanics), algorithms which allows us to calculate some desired wave parameters (such as wavenumbers) in such structures far more efficiently than before, and a new algorithm which allows researchers to more efficiently sort the solutions of eigenvalue problems (such as vibration and waves). Limitations of current metamaterial techniques were also studied. Notably, it was shown that a major issue which plagues metamaterials research is that it often ignores the realistic constraint that in practice metamaterials have to be made of finite samples and cannot be infinite in extent. The general assumption of infinite metamaterials at the stage of design leads to emergent errors when effort is made to actually create such metamaterials in practice. This disconnect is a difficult issue to resolve and during this project a limited solution to this issue was proposed. Further limitations and constraints on what metamaterial properties are physically realizable were also proposed based on the ideas of causality and passivity. An important contribution was also made towards a completely new way of studying these problems which combines ideas from neural networks and computer graphics (distance functions). In addition to several original research papers in the best journals in the field, this project also resulted in two extensive review articles - one on the topic of homogenziation and elastic metamaterials, and another on the topic of causality and passivity. The latter was the more extensive one and gives researchers a broad view of the advances made in multiple fields including wave scattering, network theory, cloaking, and metamaterials over the last 120 years.

Broader Impacts: The project has also resulted in many broader impacts. First and foremoest, it has provided research opportunities to students from under represented minority communities. These students were generally the first in their family to go to graduate school and they have been very successful post-graduation, opening their own companies and joining prestigious places like Boeing research. Further community outreach was accomplished through the organization of several workshops and conference sessions. Particularly notable are the Midwest Mechanics Workshop and the Midwest Numerical Day, both organized on IIT campus. These events were free for students to attend and they allowed the students to present their work to their peers and interact with researchers and professors from multiple midwestern universities. For the distribution of relevant tutorials and codes, a dedicated website was set up which allowed group members to share their open source codes as well as explanatory articles. The project also led to deep improvements in the curriculum in the Mechanical, Materials, and Aerospace Engineering department at IIT. Improvement were made through the introduction of python based learning at the undergraduate level courses and contemporary machine learning ideas at the graduate level courses.
